Entries.default: "The ranga nui leads us, but he represents all of Rauatai."
"Then must he put his name on everything? Prize-share is simpler."
"Why does your ranga carve his name into a rock?"
"The ranga nui. And it's a commemoration. To show what he built."

"For what do you squawk and gloat over a heap of stones? Ekera, you Rauataians are strange cousins, indeed." 

A well-dressed Huana woman shakes her head at a Rauataian man. The tone of their debate is spirited, but not unfriendly.

"The Brass Citadel is a marvel of modern engineering! With the gates barred and the cannons primed, it can withstand any attack and weather any storm."

He and his Huana friend turn to regard you.
"Why does this matter to you?"
"I'm sure the Brass Citadel is very nice."
[Leave] "I don't have time for this."
"These Rauataians act as if every bare islet is merely awaiting a fort or a farm. They cannot look at anything without planning to change it."
"Oh! Then did your Roparu also write their names on other stones?"
"I... am sorry about your queen."
"I... am sorry about your prince."
"Come, tell this outsider how foolish he sounds."
"Maybe you can get through to her, trencher."
"Your people are builders, too. Perhaps you can appreciate the value of a fine stronghold."
"To strive is to survive. Those who would achieve greatness must make the world a better, more ordered place than they found it."
"This 'rocky cove' was once a prized fishing spot for the Roparu."
"Surely you can see what a fine stronghold this is."
"We transformed a rocky cove into the best-defended harbor in Neketaka! Such achievements must be celebrated."
"Please, spare us empty pleasantries!"
"This place? It's an eyesore!"
"You stand sheltered by good stone and craftsmanship, and you complain about aesthetics?"
"It's an excellent fort. Sturdy and built to last."
"I am sure someone once said the same about the ancient places in Deadfire before storms and volcanoes made ruins of them."
"Why change the world when you can learn to live in it the way it is? This is what my people have done for thousands of years."
"Sorry, but I don't have anything to add."
"Of course it's noble and worthwhile to build great things!"
"Even the mightiest works crumble. Why waste blood and sweat on them?"
"We should ask what provides the greatest benefit - a fishing spot or a harbor?"
They both look at you with wary disapproval.
"Nothing? You cannot absent yourself from all such questions."
"Deadfire is changing. It remains to us to determine what it will become."
With that, they turn from you and resume their discussion.

"And we'll all return to the Wheel, but that does not stop us from living a full life now."

He snorts, but there's something good-natured in his disagreement.
"But for what purpose? And at what cost?" She spreads her hands to you in question, but she isn't angry.
"Must we sacrifice the needs of the few to the whims of the many, then?" She spreads her hands to you in question, but she isn't angry.
"Ekera, nothing invigorates like a good discussion. Thank you for indulging us." She grins.
"The world is bigger than us. It does not need our hand to guide its change."

"And wild barley grows on its own, but most of it dies without a skilled farmer."

He snorts, but there's something good-natured in his disagreement.
"Will your mighty fortress protect you from the adra colossus?"
"Much better than wooden huts, my friend!"
"You cannot stand against such a force. You can only flee it."
"We are greater than rulers and figureheads. Or have you learned nothing?"
"Perhaps one day we can be one people again. As in ancient times."
"You build your history like you build your monuments. All in service to conquest."
"Our chanters say we once came from Deadfire. How can we be so different?"
"There is so little we understand of one another."
